At 12:19, you can simply skip using Sarrus' rule for the 3x3 matrix. Since it has all 0s on one side of the diagonal, you can simply directly multiply the elements along the diagonal to get the determinant. This applies regardless of whether the 0s are on the top right or bottom left. You could also perform row operations until the matrix becomes triangular, then multiply along the diagonal to get the determinant.

It's arbitrary what we choose as our starting component for finding eigenvectors, because all that ultimately matters is the direction.  In most applications, they will be scaled by a constant anyway, that will depend on other information like initial conditions.  For best simplicity, you have three options: 1. Pick one component, and arbitrarily assign it to the value of 1. 2. If you end up with a fraction for the remaining component(s), then you multiply all components by the same constant, until they all are integers. 3. Reduce it to a unit vector, if desired.   This usually isn't desired.
Yes, because they both can be scaled by a constant to equal the other.  It is generally simplest form to scale them by a constant, until you have an integer for each term.
All entries below the leading entry or diagonal must be equal to zero. However it's still accepted if all the values at the end of the matrix is zero

If the starting matrix is a singular matrix, then zero will be at least one of the eigenvalues.  Zero could also be a repeated eigenvalue, depending on the how many linearly dependent pairs of rows the matrix has (i.e. rows that are constant multiples of each other).  For the case of a 2x2 matrix, the only 2x2 matrix with zero as a repeated eigenvalue, is the zero matrix.  Any singular 2x2 matrix will have zero and some other number, as its eigenvalues.  For the case of a 3x3 matrix, you could have zero as a single eigenvalue, or a twice-repeated eigenvalue.  As a single eigenvalue, it indicates that the matrix contains only one pair of rows that are a scalar multiple of each other, with the remaining row being independent.  As a twice-repeated eigenvalue, it indicates that all three rows of the matrix are constant scalar multiples of each other.

Yes.  There are an infinite number of eigenvectors associated with any given eigenvalue and any given matrix.  You need to arbitrarily assume one of the components, and any non-zero scalar multiple of said eigenvector is a valid solution.

In the application to differential equations, you will start with a system of diffEQ's that can be represented by a matrix: dx/dt = a*x + b*y dy/dt = c*x + d*y  This can be written in terms of capital X and capital A, where capital X is the vertical matrix containing x and y, and capital A is the square matrix containing the coefficients.  X' will refer to the vertical matrix of derivatives of x and y. X' = A*X  Suppose the eigenvalues of A are λ1 and λ2, and the corresponding eigenvectors of A are V1 and V2.  When the two eigenvalues are real and distinct, the solution for matrix X will be: X = k1*V1*e^(λ1*t) + k2*V2*e^(λ2*t) k1 and k2 are arbitrary scalar constants, that you'd solve for with initial conditions.  Other cases of eigenvalues have forms that are mathematically related to this, like complex eigenvalues will have a combination of sine and cosine, enveloped by an exponential term.  The real part is the exponential growth/decay rate, and the imaginary part will give the frequency for the sine and cosine.  Suppose V1 = <V1x, V1y>, and V2 = <V2x, V2y>.   Translating this matrix equation to a pair of equations, we get: x = k1*V1x*e^(λ1*t) + k2*V2x*e^(λ2*t) y = k1*V1y*e^(λ1*t) + k2*V2y*e^(λ2*t)  So in summary, the eigenvalues are the exponential growth rates (or decay rates) for the terms of the solution, and the eigenvectors establish the proportionality between corresponding exponential terms in the solution for each variable.

A real life application of this concept, is the startup characteristics of a motor.  This theory allows you to use the design of the windings and the mechanical properties of the rotor, to predict how fast it settles to its steady state condition, and the overshoot for speed and current.  The variables x and y would represent rotor speed and current drawn from the source.   This application also has constant terms added to each equation, for the voltage applied, and the load torque.  This is the equation system in question: L*I'(t) = -R*I(t) - K*ω(t) + V J*ω'(t) = K*I(t) - D*ω(t) - τ  Variables: I(t) = current, ω(t) = rotation speed  Electrical properties: L: inductance of windings, R: winding parasitic resistance, V: Voltage of DC source, K: proportionality constant between current and torque, based on winding geometry and magnetic field strength.  Mechanical: J: moment of inertia, D: Drag constant, assuming proportional drag, τ: torque of load.

There are an infinite number of possible Eigenvectors for any given matrix and eigenvalue.  They all are ultimately proportional to each other, and only differ by a scalar multiple.  Therefore, to keep it simple, you arbitrarily select 1 as one of the components of the eigenvector, and find consistent values for the other components.  It doesn't matter which component we arbitrarily set to 1, as long as it doesn't produce divide by zero errors for the other eigenvector components.  If desired, you can multiply the entire vector by another scalar to clear the fractions in an eigenvector.   For instance, if I find that <1, 2/3> is my eigenvector, I would strategically multiply each component by 3, to clear the fraction, and get <3, 2> instead of <1, 2/3>.

Yes, that is called the trace of the matrix.  The determinant is the product of the eigenvalues.  The trace and determinant are two values that can be used as shortcuts to finding the eigenvalues more directly.  Call the mean of the diagonal, m, which will be half the trace of the matrix. Call the determinant p, for the product of the eigenvalues.  The solution for eigenvalues: m +/- sqrt(m^2 - p)
so is it the right answer as well? or is it wrong?

It is arbitrary how large you define the eigenvectors to be, or which term to which you assign a value.  But to keep it simple, you usually default to assigning one of the components of them to be unity, and you usually default to assigning it to the first element (x1).   You can assign x1 to be 314 if you like, and the other terms of the eigenvector will follow proportionally.  It is common that in applications of eigenvectors, it doesn't matter how large you make the eigenvectors, as their magnitude ends up cancelling out of the equation.
I had same issue. Same magnitude of eigen vectors but reversed signs. Is it acceptable?

You can choose either number to equal 1, or even something else entirely, when establishing the eigenvectors, as long as it isn't zero.   It's usually convention to pick 1, because it keeps it simple.   But you can strategically chose another number, to clear your fractions.  For instance, consider the matrix: [ 1, 6 ] [ 4, -1]  The two eigenvalues are lambda1 = -5 and lambda2 = -5.  For lambda1, the eigenvector is <1, -1>. I could also write this as <-1, 1>, or even <-5, 5> if I wanted to.  I'd likely choose the one with one of the components being 1, for simplicity.  It doesn't matter which one I choose to be 1.  All that matters is that I produce a vector that has this proportion between its components.   In any differential equation application, I'd usually multiply the eigenvector by an arbitrary constant anyway, which will take care of the arbitrary choice of which eigenvector component to assume, and my initial conditions will determine this arbitrary constant.  For lambda2, if I let the first component of the eigenvector be 1, the eigenvector will be <1, 2/3>.   Maybe if I'd prefer not to have fractions, i'd strategically write it as <3, 2>.   I don't necessarily have to have the first component be 1, just because the first component was 1 in the eigenvector of lambda1.

12:20 We could also use following determinant property: If matrix "A" is either a upper triangular matrix, a lower triangular matrix or a diagonal matrix, then its determinant is equal to product of the items from its main diagonal. For example: Case 1) "A" is upper triangular matrix: | 1 2 3 | | 0 5 6 | | 0 0 9 | Then det(A) = 1 * 5 * 9 Case 2) "A" is lower triangular matrix: | 1 0 0 | | 4 5 0 | | 7 8 9 | Then det(A) = 1 * 5 * 9 Case 3) "A" is diagonal matrix: | 1 0 0 | | 0 5 0 | | 0 0 9 | Then det(A) = 1 * 5 * 9 Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Determinant#Properties_of_the_determinant See rule number "7.".

AAAHHH!  Quantum class flashbacks!!!! Seriously, I noticed the lack of viewers on this.  It's just a case of people being afraid of math.  Kudos to everyone who watched the whole thing. 7:20  This is why mathematicians hate physicists.  "OK, let's set the speed of light to 1 with no units.  We'll put it back in when we need it." 15:40 You can think of the "free variable" as integration in calculus.  When you take the derivative of an equation, you lose the finale constant.  When you turn around and integrate the equation, you an add a constant of any value.  IRL, acceleration is the derivative of velocity.  Going the other way, velocity is the integral of acceleration.  So what's the +c?  It's your starting velocity.  For example, you are in your car and accelerate 1 kph/sec.  So how fast are you going after 10 seconds?  One bit of information is missing, that is, your initial velocity.  It's the difference between hitting the gas when the light turns green, verses hitting the gas to pass a slow poke.   However, this matrix math can only be solved for integral values, which pretty much is basis of quantum mechanics,  As I've told people before, you really can't understand the whys and hows of QM without doing the math.
